title: Will there be a new episode of mass killing in Democratic Republic of Congo before 1 January 2017?
preds: Kabila has been prepping for months because he expects it ...its starting now and will escalate. How many die before January 1 makes the question tricky as the rioting is just starting now.

How long does it take for a mass killing to occur? More than 10 days? This question has been unusually problematic because the real trouble was always likely to begin very late in the year. That time is now, and there's no telling what might happen in the last few days of 2016: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/dec/18/congo-braces-for-violence-president-mandate-expires
I would like to know what is the definition of mass killing, however I will use the same estimated I have for Nigeria.
Adjusting down for the passage of time.

Plausible now.
https://www.yahoo.com/news/dr-congo-president-defies-growing-calls-resign-174446567.html
Anger over the delay has sparked violence including street clashes in September that killed dozens.
https://www.yahoo.com/news/congo-leader-claims-interference-amid-vote-delay-tension-163807584.html
Leaving historical forecast to cover any remaining odds.
December protests in DRC during time election was supposed to be held
Down 5% for passage of time and question criteria.

Up another 4% on this: 'The U.N.’s top diplomat in the Democratic Republic of Congo warned Tuesday the country has “entered a period of extreme risk to its stability,” as the electoral crisis deepens. . .“Actors on all sides appear more and more willing to resort to violence to achieve their ends, while the space for constructive political activity has shrunk further still,” he said. “If this trajectory continues, I believe large-scale violence is all but inevitable,” http://www.voanews.com/a/united-nations-democratic-republic-of-congo-election-kabila/3545781.html - Seems like a reasonable prediction, although tying a start-date on it is problematic.
Situation in Beni also pretty dire: http://www.africanews.com/2016/10/04/drc-icc-urged-to-probe-beni-massacres/

The potential for increased political violence can be viewed as an outcome of the electorate's view of the constitutional system in DRC.  The real question is not whether it will occur or not (I suggest it will), but rather the scale or intensity of state violence will destabilize the political system.   With the UN peacekeepers in DRC minimized against the population's discontent, they will not be able to maintain stability between the government and its endogenous discontents.

Up 2% now that postponement of elections is official. 1000 fatalities is a high bar to reach in three months but this is a big country and unrest will be widespread. Close watch. 
http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/us-orders-families-of-govt-personnel-to-leave-drc-20160930
EWP's Expert Opinion Pool is at 5% but there is a potential for violence since it doesn't look like President Kabila intends to step down despite the term limit.
Highly unlikely.  Current levels of civilian killing would have to more than quintuple to hit 1,000 for the year, and that's by all actors.
Passage of time and consensus is low.
up slightly on current violence connected with protests.  watching

Down 12%, mainly because I've been high on this one for a while, but also because it takes a helluva lot of violence to get anywhere near 1000 casualties. 
The tricky bit is that the usual "passage of time" qualifier doesn't work here, because intense unrest has always been most likely to occur around election time - at the very end of the year. Taking Burundi as a similar - though much smaller - model, it is highly probable that there'll be widespread fatalities, but nowhere near enough to count as an EWP "mass killing".
Plus 3 on crowd view very unlikely.

https://www.crisisgroup.org/africa/central-africa/democratic-republic-congo/katanga-tensions-drcs-mineral-heartland The Crisis Group describes the situation as "unchanged" for the last few months, but warns that there may be trouble brewing in Katanga province.
Pushing up to 6 on reports of large massacres in eastern Congo and continuing violence in their wake.

316 deaths in the last 4 months of this year. At that rate 948 deaths for this year, close to 1000 threshold.  The United Nations is concerned that the current political impasse will also lead to violence.Tens of thousands of people rallied in the Democratic Republic of Congo’s capital calling on President Joseph Kabila to step down and a political challenger said his attempt to return was blocked, as tensions intensify in Africa’s top copper producer. http://www.cfr.org/africa-sub-saharan/sub-saharan-security-tracker/p37884
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-08-01/congo-opposition-raise-stakes-as-rally-urges-kabila-to-step-down-irbpa0sw Conflicts The Eastern part of the DRC continues to be the theatre of a complex and chronic humanitarian crisis. As of May 2016, the United Nation Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported a total 1.8 million of Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) due to armed attacks and violence between the DRC armed forces (FARDC) and armed groups, mainly in Southern and Eastern DRC. An upsurge of violence and massive population movement have been taken place due to the resurgence of armed groups wishing to claim independence for the province of the Haut-Katanga and to the spreading of ethnic tensions between Nande and Hutu communities in North-Kivu.
http://reliefweb.int/report/democratic-republic-congo/drc-humanitarian-situation-report-may-june-2016
Down 2% to be below the consensus.

(no change for now) I’ve resigned myself to NOT getting any further clarification from EWP on what constitutes a mass killing. (Consequently, I’ve not elected to join the more recent questions.) Looking at part of the EWP definitions, I’d like to offer an opinion about two points related to this phrase: “targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less” 1. I now believe (but wouldn’t be surprised if EWP made a clarification that contradicted this) that the period related to any specific question starts when the question is introduced and runs through the end of CY 2016. (I believe the other ideas that it either looks back in a running period of a year or is the whole calendar year are wrong.) 2. There are at least two interpretations of which group(s) are targeted. A narrow interpretation is that whatever government (“in” tribe) forces there are target only a specific subset of the population. Then there is a broader interpretation that any significant deaths that are not combat related or otherwise proscribed would count (in the sense that those targeted are “outsiders” in some sense). I lean now toward accepting either, but probably put less weight on the latter as I think about a particular situation.

(no change) First is EWP’s answer on the GJO questions: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/281886 One can either interpret it to mean the clock started when the question opened or try to parse this quote “over the course of the year, without regard to calendar year.” Second is the web page for the EWP expert opinion pool: http://www.earlywarningproject.com/opinion_pools (As you will note, the latter is for a calendar year. EWP tries to be clear that there are differences between the Expert Opinion Pool criteria and the GJO questions.) I’m updating my “understanding” so that I can find it easily and don’t have to guess: 1. The time frame for this episode starts on 8 March 2016 and ends 31 December 2016. (Please feel free to weigh in to explain the unexplainable.)
Updating for passage of time. Current situation doesn't point towards mass killings.

(no change) (no change) Here is one link I've relied on to confirm that the EWP questions are for the full calendar year 2016: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/244986 I interpret this as confirming that it is for a full calendar year (if not otherwise specified).
Down 10% to be closer to consensus.
Down 5% to be closer to consensus.

Down from 12 to 10 on passage of time, plus sharp slowdown in first half of June in rate of civilian fatalities recorded by ACLED. I read the latter as evidence that the recent spate of protests is not going to escalate into sustained rebellion, to which the state might respond with extreme violence. That could still happen later this year, but it does not seem to be happening now, and I think that marginally reduces the probability of it happening at all this year.

This is a tricky one, especially now that the opposition parties are beginning to unite against Kabila. All the elements for widespread violence appear to be in place, and postponed or cancelled elections could turn very nasty. But, but, but. . . 
Will those opposed to Kabila's extended rule be willing to accept a postponement if there are clear signs of progress toward an election in early 2017?
Will an announcement of Kabila's intentions come too late in the year to see this question resolved in the affirmative?
Will the lure of DRC's immense natural riches encourage Europe, China and the US to intervene? (Cash flow always matters more than blood flow)
Will the united opposition remain united? Unity is a very rare thing in a land with more than 250 distinct ethnic groups. 
Down 20% on earlier forecasts, but still higher than most expert opinions.
Even for a volatile region, one thousand deaths in a single incident (or series of related incidents) is a fairly high threshold.
Increasing estimate due to increased likelihood of violence (although not necessarily mass killings) in DRC due to electoral processes and so on.

Reducing nominally from 13% last month, to reflect EPW's Expert Opinion Pool which has declined to 5% from 7% last month. However, there were still a few dozen fatalities reported in May.
http://www.earlywarningproject.com/countries/democratic-republic-of-the-congo From ACLED's monthy report on the DRC,
 "Insecurity in the Eastern DR-Congo has remained relatively stable with both the number of events and fatalities over the last 6 months comparable to the average over the past 5 years (see Figure 4). This is despite continued military offensives, such as renewed efforts by FARDC and MONUSCO to root out ADF bases in Beni territory (Radio Okapi, 23 May 2016). Although this cooperation has produced victories for the military forces, ADF rebels continue to show their ability to carry out high fatality attacks on civilians, with at least 30 killed in early May by the group (AFP, 11 May 2016). Similarly, offensives against the
FDLR, APCLS and Raia Mutomboki militias have all produced modest gains, notably in terms of recovered territory, but have failed to produce decisive victories or
lasting results."
http://www.acleddata.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/ACLED_Conflict-Trends-Report-No.49-June-2016_pdf.pdf The international Crisis Group's latest report essentially says "no change"
DR Congo  |  1 Jun 2016 Unchanged
"Constitutional court 11 May ruled that President Kabila could legally stay in office after his second term ends in Dec if elections have not been held. Main opposition parties rejected judgement, called for protest marches. Anti-govt protests held throughout country 26 May, clashed with police in several cities, one protester and one policeman killed in Goma. Ex-Katanga Governor Moïse Katumbi 4 May said he would run in presidential elections; govt same day opened investigation into Katumbi’s alleged hiring of foreign mercenaries in plot against govt. Prosecutor general 19 May issued arrest warrant for him but Katumbi flew with prosecutor’s permission to South Africa 20 May for medical treatment, 27 May flew to Europe. Attacks on civilians rose in eastern Beni territory, North Kivu, attributed to Allied Democratic Forces (ADF) rebels, leaving at least twenty people dead; armed forces 14 May launched new operation against ADF."
http://www.crisisgroup.org/en/publication-type/crisiswatch/crisiswatch-database.aspx?CountryIDs=%7bC076CDFE-2B2D-4642-8895-5EF27AE4E416%7d#results
Up 10% on slightly better understanding of the scheduled election and @troyburns

Up 4%. Recent protests were minor in terms of violence (only 2 killed!) but suggestive of disillusionment and discontent that could shake things up on a larger scale later in year. Not sure that this can be avoided even if Kabila decides not to delay elections. http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/05/drc-braced-protests-planned-opposition-160526050328405.html
Fascinating HRW piece from last year - https://www.hrw.org/news/2015/07/28/joseph-kabila-forever-dangers-extended-presidency-democratic-republic-congo - Trying to understand Kabila isn't easy, but I suspect his political maneuvering isn't just a grab for power - he genuinely sees himself as the best man to lead DRC. Sadly, he may be right.
Adjustment due to current volatility and repression against opposition.
no end in sight for political instability.
Tempted to up my call based on Katumbi's arrest warrant but initial 2:1 forecast still seems about right. Interesting analysis from Ben Shepherd: http://allafrica.com/stories/201605201207.html
Up 5% on Kabila issuing  warrant for opposition leader.

Heading toward the reality or postponement of November elections, tensions will build. Instability and violence in neighboring countries likely to exacerbate this. High probability of widespread violence late in year - but will it be too late to meet EWP threshold? Early deferment of elections will have a big effect on prognostications, I suspect. A couple of articles suggesting a storm's-a-comin': http://www.undispatch.com/elections-in-the-democratic-republic-of-congo-could-mean-trouble/ and http://allafrica.com/stories/201605170512.html

Increasing my prediction a bit. Khalid provided a great link from crisis group that showed "modest progress" towards a political dialogue (May 2nd). On the 12th, however, a court cleared Kabila to remain in power if the election were delayed. I believe that sets a lower bar for what needs to happen for Kabila to retain power and, therefore, for actions to be taken against him: http://www.newsweek.com/dr-congo-third-term-fears-mount-court-clears-kabila-remain-power-if-elections-459107 "Kabila’s government has already dropped hints that the elections are likely to be delayed, although the president himself has not declared if he will try to amend the constitution to allow him to stay in power. "  If Kabila's telling the truth (hard to tell with DRC politicians), then not amending the constitution would be in the right direction. I don't have a good idea of what probability to attribute to that sort of a statement. Court ruling + protests occurring in opposition to it: increase by 1.5%. Meanwhile, in Burundi, the president declared he would stand for a 3rd term despite constitutional restrictions. Rebel groups are forming up in neighboring countries, and the govt is inciting dangerous ethnic rhetoric. Burundi is home to Hutus and Tutsi clans, similar to Rwanda, which borders Burundi to the north and DRC to the east. Hundreds of thousands of refugees are beginning to flee Burundi. Seeing as one of the major causes of the 1st Congo Civil war was the refugee crisis caused in the east DRC after the Rwanda genocide, I believe a growing refugee crisis increases the risk of a mass killing episode in the DRC.  Burundi crisis - I increase by 2% given history of refugee crises causing wars in DRC. THEN, there was also a slaugher in the Kivu region of 40-50 people.  Since this tally counts towards  the definition of "mass killing" as I understand it in this question, then it by definition increases the probability of hitting that 500 #. http://www.christiantoday.com/article/drc.worship.leader.and.deacon.among.9.people.killed.by.islamist.militants/85929.htm
Also increase by 2.5% (i could be more accurate here if I knew the current fully tally of civilian killings this year. But I don't. Does anyone know where to find this?) 1.5% + 2% + 2.5 % = 6% increase to 24% given recent developments.

The starting point as is usual for me is EPW's Expert Opinion Pool, currently 7%, compared to the GJopen consensus of 19%.  Also, compared to its update of last month, the International Crisis Group reports "modest progress towards political dialogue". Consequently, I'm reducing from last month's 17%.
http://www.crisisgroup.org/en/publication-type/crisiswatch/crisiswatch-database.aspx?CountryIDs=%7bC076CDFE-2B2D-4642-8895-5EF27AE4E416%7d#results
"DR Congo  |  2 May 2016Unchanged
Modest progress made toward political dialogue, as protestors clashed with security forces in ex-Katanga province. AU 6 April appointed former Togolese PM Edem Kodjo as facilitator of national political dialogue, however opposition parties except Union for Democracy and Social Progress (UDPS) maintained refusal to take part. Electoral Commission 15 April said creation of new voter list would start July, could take three years. In ex-Katanga province, rising crime and murder of two people 17 April in Kolwezi sparked protest against security services; four protesters killed. Tensions increased in Lubumbashi as incidents at offices of political parties that recently joined opposition and are close to former governor now opposition leader Moïse Katumbi 19 April triggered protests and clashes with security forces. Security forces in Lubumbashi 24 April dispersed crowd with shots and tear gas before Katumbi rally, arrested his supporters and bodyguards. In North Kivu province, army renewed offensives against rebel groups including Rwandan Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR), claimed displaced people in Masisi hiding rebels in camps; authorities late March began closing four camps, by 13 April forcing some 35,000 people to move on. FDLR late March-early April reportedly tried twice to cross from DRC into Rwanda, causing Rwandan army to increase troops along border."
Down 15% to be closer to consensus.
Increase in estimate to to volatility and instability around the conflict of having/not having elections for an unconstitutional third term for the current president.   Likely to over time.
Historical data suggests a probability of 25%.  Past trends continue.
These early warning updates today unlike all others rely exclusively on comments and updates from other participating. I hope to catch up with the news this weekend. If there is any news.
Volatile, but unlikely to meet the definition.
UN peace mission in Congo is working, and no new reports have come along recently indicating spread of violence there.

There are multiple international bodies and agencies following the election and the process. The eyes of the world are on the country so to speak. As such, this makes the act of mass atrocity low, especially as even the armed groups are waiting, from reading, many of the actors involved still seem to want progress. However, I put 21% as the country is still very unstable and with the presence of so many actors there is still a chance for change.    http://www.africanews.com/2016/04/18/international-bodies-to-send-support-missions-to-drc/

Upping my forecast from 8 to 12 percent on signs that the government is willing to use lethal and indiscriminate force in response to political threats associated with the upcoming elections. The key piece of new evidence is this statement from Amnesty International about recent air strikes in a residential neighborhood: https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2016/04/republic-of-congo-air-strikes-hit-residential-areas-including-schools/

Over the last five years fatalities in the DRC, as tracked by ACLED (a US Government sponsored organization) have fallen roughly between 1,000 and 2,000 per year.  With some exceptions (e.g. the discovery of a mass grave last year containing 450 corpses), most violent incidents result in few casualties and the combatants range widely (though government security forces, unsurprisingly, are generally involved in the higher casualty events.)  While violence may increase in 2016 over 2015 (and preceding years) due to election violence or spillover from Burundi civil unrest, a mass killing against a single group that results in 1,000 noncombatant casualties is a tall order.  If the elections take an especially ethnic tone or if the Burundi government perceives elements of the DRC population is willfully harboring rebels (especially after a significant violent event), the probability of mass killing will increase.

Consensus is 28% compared to EWP's Expert Opinion Pool at 6% http://www.earlywarningproject.com/opinion_pools/111 I propose to continue to split the difference, but elections (whether held on schedule or not) could increase violence abruptly. "DR Congo  |  1 Apr 2016Unchanged
Political crisis continued with no significant progress toward dialogue, and elections planned for Nov increasingly likely to be delayed. Electoral commission (CENI) 18 March said it could not organise presidential and legislative elections for Nov 2016 as planned due to extensive voter roll update, matter will likely be referred to constitutional court; ruling coalition insists on need for dialogue, opposition continues to refuse, but apparently willing to meet AU mediator Edem Kodjo. G7 group of opposition parties 30 March announced it would back ex-Katanga Governor Moïse Katumbi as presidential candidate if he runs. Indirect elections of provincial governors held 26 March in all but one of 21 newly established provinces after CENI and courts rejected most opposition candidacies. Ruling coalition claimed victory in fifteen provinces, including four created by division of mineral-rich former Katanga province. In South Ubangi province, governor election delayed due to contested election of provincial assembly president. Final results to be published 12 April. In further sign of shrinking free speech, govt 11 March closed La Voix du Katanga radio and television station. UN attack helicopters 24 March engaged Allied Democratic Force (ADF) rebels. UNSC 30 March extended MONUSCO’s mandate for one year, rejecting govt’s appeal to downsize mission."
http://www.crisisgroup.org/en/publication-type/crisiswatch/crisiswatch-database.aspx?CountryIDs=%7bC076CDFE-2B2D-4642-8895-5EF27AE4E416%7d#results

Enormous amount of armed groups in the Congo, plus ongoing ethnic violence. http://www.enoughproject.org/conflicts/eastern_congo/armed-groups
http://www.newsweek.com/ethnic-violence-dr-congo-kills-least-21-un-424649?piano_t=1

Racial violence continues to be a factor contributing to the ongoing strife in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Though this past election was relatively stable, violence continues in its aftermath. It is difficult to say with certainty that this will result in a large-scale atrocity, but it is not outside the historic norm for the region.

I have not seen any evidence that the root causes of the mass killings in DRP of Congo have been or will be addressed in the near future.   Congo is like the San Andreas Fault - it's not a question of if, but rather of when.
Up 5% until possible elections play out.

The electoral situation in the DRC seems to be ripe for political unrest and violence but given the interest of the International community in the political affairs of the DRC, it would seem that the opportunity for "mass killing", as defined in this survey, by the Kabila government seems to be limited if he would like to retain power.  Thus, the question is whether "mass killing" could result from the instigation of violence by Kabali's opponents?  Again because of International scrutiny, as well as the desire of his opponents to retain "human rights credibility", the probability is very low that a mass killing will occur before January 1, 2017.
Kabila will violate condition and there will be violence but not mass killing
While the rule of law is weak, I don't think the structural conditions are uniformly in favor of such an event

Increasing my prediction. Prior forecast: 15%, which is significantly higher than EWP. New forecast: 18%.  +0.5% - Rebels killed a park ranger in eastern Congo, which has been the starting point for a lot of prior violence (Great likes, North/South Kivu): http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/suspected-rebels-kill-ranger-congo-park-38077317 +1% - Violence breaks out in Brazzaville, capital of neighboring Republic of Congo. If elections lead to increased political in RoC, could increase risk of spillover to DRC: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/gun-battles-rock-brazzaville-in-wake-of-disputed-republic-of-congo-election/2016/04/04/f028268e-fa91-11e5-9140-e61d062438bb_story.html 1% - Congo opposition parties endorse Katumbi: http://www.voanews.com/content/congo-opposition-parties-endorse-powerful-ex-governor-president/3261840.html 0.5% - Story just broke about children being held w/o any indictment in eastern Congo, could re-stir ethnic tensions (they are accused of being FDLR): https://www.hrw.org/news/2016/04/04/dr-congo-children-held-remote-military-prison +1% - Liquidity issues w/ large Congolese bank. Bank run could set of an unpredictable chain of events leading to greater violence: http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-04/congo-s-central-bank-moves-to-stabilize-biac-as-it-urges-calm Neutral, but watching: Kabila's sister named in Panama Papers release. I'm not sure what effect this will have, but could imagine opposition using it as rallying point against corrupt: http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/drc-presidents-sister-named-in-panama-papers-20160404 The 1,000 figure seems increasingly plausible to me depending on what Kabila decides.  In neighboring Burundi, a much smaller country (~10mm population vs DRCs ~68mm), 400 ppl were killed when President Nkurunziza decided to run for a 3rd term. In Rwanda, Kagame has run for a third term, and Uganda's Museveni is trying to extend his rule as well. 
http://www.newsweek.com/dr-congo-how-do-you-solve-problem-kabila-428152
http://www.newsweek.com/uganda-elections-museveni-besigye-and-mbabazi-prepare-face-polls-414541?rx=us
http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/02/uganda-museveni-set-extend-30-year-rule-160220081603679.html All of these countries (Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi) have played critical roles in the Congolese civil wars over the last 20+ years.

Nudging up to 8 percent on rising risk of election-related violence, which presents a couple of pathways to mass killing: 1) state-led violence against protesters and apparent sympathizers, and 2) the emergence of an armed rebellion in response to state repression, and then state-led mass killing of civilians who apparently support or sympathize with the rebels.
Bajo la definición dada veo muy difícil un episodio de ese tipo  en el congo
Up 10% to be above the consensus.
Congo is not a country of law and order!!!
in november 2016 new elections will be held therefore all remain quiet.

     And Congo is no Burundi...."  
However there is a sizeable UN mission just renewed today, multiple ICC prosecutions and extraditions. The New York TImes article seems misleading.
whoever is in KInshasa the UN will be in the Congo. 
Today the UN renewed its mission
http://www.un.org/press/en/2016/sc12307.doc.htm
Security Council Authorizes Mandate Renewal for United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo
The Security Council today renewed until 31 March 2017 the mandate of the United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (MONUSCO), including its Intervention Brigade, deciding to maintain its current force levels. Unanimously adopting resolution 2277 (2016) under Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter, the Council took note of the Secretary-General’s recommendation to reduce MONUSCO’s force level by 1,700 troops, taking into account the progress made in developing an exit strategy and in addressing the threat posed by armed groups. Recalling the 2,000-troop reduction endorsed in resolution 2211 (2015), the Council reaffirmed its intention to make that downsizing permanent through a revised troop ceiling, and requested that the Secretary-General report back on that specific issue.  It reiterated that any future reconfigurations of MONUSCO and its mandate should be determined in consultation with the Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, based on the evolution of the situation on the ground. The Council decided that MONUSCO’s strategic priorities would contribute to the protection of civilians from violence — including gender-based violence and violence against children — and stabilization, including by supporting the creation of an environment conducive to peaceful, credible and timely elections.  It requested that the Mission consider child protection and gender considerations as cross-cutting issues across its mandate, and that the Secretary-General take necessary measures to ensure MONUSCO’s full compliance with the United Nations zero-tolerance policy on sexual exploitation and abuse.  The Council urged troop-and police-contributing countries to take preventive actions and ensure full accountability in cases of such conduct involving their personnel. By other terms, the Council stressed that MONUSCO’s exit should be “gradual and progressive” and tied to targets jointly developed with the Government.  Specifically, it reiterated the need for a clear exit strategy for the Intervention Brigade — which, according to the text, had been extended on an exceptional basis, without creating a precedent or prejudice to the agreed principles of peacekeeping — including through progress in ending the threat posed by armed groups.  The Council strongly condemned all armed groups operating in the region, demanding that they immediately end the violence, permanently disband, lay down their arms and release children from their ranks".

Mostly just noting this to remind myself later.
For DRC, the on-going episode is state-led, but I'm not entirely sure which military forces that would imply, for instance in looking at the actors in ACLED data.  I'm assuming that means not the Military Forces of DRC or Police Forces of DRC - neither of which are accounting for that many fatalities recently.  There were a large number (425) of civilian deaths last April with "unidentified armed forces" as the perpetrator.  (Mass grave found with 420 bodies in town near Kinshasa)  That incident is much larger than anything else recorded for the last year. Potential other military-force related episodes:  ADF-NALU (accounted for 204 in the past year - relatively evenly spread out over the year) and FDLR ( 120 in the past year - most in late 2015 )   Seems like this particular question hinges on whether there is election related violence.  The UN envoy to DRC has been warning the UN on this: http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=53527#.VvnCcj-u_wc   The elections are supposed to be in late November.

The DRC has been witness to terrible tragedy over the last 2 decades. Last couple of years seem to be getting (relatively) better. Some rebel groups have turned in their guns in exchange for political cooperation. Kabila has been in power since the end of the 2nd Congolese civil war, and has been consolidating his power vis-a-vis governor elections. This has will likely strengthen his hold on security forces, which could discourage new rebel groups from intervening. Although it's hard to tell how solid the security forces are, as Congo strongmen have historically maintained power through a divide and conquer strategy that weakens state institutions, including security forces. I think the question may be a bit ambiguous.  "New mass killing" episode is classified as over 1,000 civilian deaths over a 1 year period.  Does that mean 1 year period starting Jan 1 2016, or Jan 1 2017? When would the decision be made?  Would the 550 civilians killed in the Beni massacres count? http://allafrica.com/stories/201603280235.html I think the major trigger will be whether or not Kabila attempts to secure a 3rd term for himself, which he is constitutionally not allowed to do but hasn't stopped other "progressive" minded African leaders like Paul Kagame in recent years. We don't know how that'll play out in DRC in Oct-Nov. There may very well be massacres, but a single event where 1,000 people are killed would require a very rapid escalation of events, beyond mass protests that could easily result from anti-Kabila sentiment, and it seems like the trend of rebel groups have been to put guns down last couple of years rather than pick them up.  Not to mention that organizing rebel groups is not an instantaneous process.  For that reason I'm rating this somewhat low, since trigger events to any sort of massive civil strife on the order witnesses in the 2 Congolese civil wars would likely occur towards the end of this year. However, I don't fully understand in what time period (1 year starting when?) that 1,000 tally would be counted. Some clarification here would be helpful.

Having spent a decent amount of time researching militant groups within the Congo, I'm aware of the country's unfortunate history of conflict, which often results is noncombatant deaths. That being said, since 2014 there has been a modicum of political stability within the country. After the expiration of the M-23 rebellion, it appears that the final remnants of 2nd Congo-War related militant groups have been put to rest.  Thats not to say that a new group of ex-militants couldn't break from the DDRR program and enter conflict again. Most of the groups that agreed to DDRR have been inactive for several years, my bet is that the risk of recidivism is low.  ADF-NALU is still active in North Kivu. Most of their aggression is guided towards Uganda, however,  it has recently been directed toward Congolese forces. If there were to be an episode of mass killing in the DRC between now and Jan 1st, my bet is that ADF-NALU would be responsible. I still don't think it is likely, the group is small, and likely lacks the organizational/material capacity to engage in violence that could result in 1k noncombatant deaths in the next 7 months. Nor do they have the incentive to do so.

There is a history of mass killings  in the Democratic Republic of  Congo. The fact that there is a precedence of mass killings  in this country  makes it likely that there  will be a new episode of mass killing in the DRC before 1 January 2017.

At least seventy armed groups are believed to be currently operating in the eastern region of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Despite the stabilizing presence of nineteen thousand UN peacekeepers, the stronger militant groups in the region, like the Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR) and the Ugandan Allied Democratic Forces (ADF), continue to terrorize communities and control weakly governed areas of the country, financing their activities by exploiting the country’s rich natural resources. Millions of civilians have been forced to flee the fighting: the United Nations estimates that currently there are at least 2.7 million internally displaced persons in the DRC and approximately 430,000 DRC refugees from in other nations.  In addition to the violence caused by armed groups, President Joseph Kabila has caused further political instability by indicating a possible desire to delay the upcoming 2016 election and to stay in power after his term ends. In December 2015, Kabila called for “political dialogue” with opposition parties, but the police have violently cracked down on internal dissent. This includes the November 2015 use of tear gas against student protesters and the breakup of a January 2015 protest, in which police fired shots and killed over forty people. Conflict in the DRC is worsening with significant political instability.   I suspect that some violence will be a precursor to the election as well as post election environment.   A high degree of uncertainty exists in the DRC and reporting on the conflict is somewhat limited.

DRC experienced an onset of mass killings in 2015 and is currently rated with the highest risk for an onset and likely increase in 2016.  DRC maintained its pairwise ranking from 2015 to 2016 compared to risks in other countries engaged in conflict.  These wiki survey rankings should be considered relative.

Hmm.   Well, Kabila's term end this year, and he's not, constitutionally, eligible for re-election.  There were mass protests last year when they tried to slip by a bill that would let him remain President until a census was completed (which the war in eastern DRC could have allowed to be indefinite).

My experience from GJP warns that getting information about the DRC (as for the Central African Republic) is difficult, and I have little or no prior background to start with. I'm going to rely heavily on the EPW's own site plus comments here. EPW's statistical risk assessment has the DRC at #7, behind Myanmar, Nigeria, Sudan, Egypt, CAR and South Sudan. Their crowd-sourced wikisurvey has the DRC at the highest risk of all. The expert opinion poll allocates a 6% chance fairly steadily since the beginning of this year. So conditions look ripe for a flare up, but there are no immediate signs.

I'm forecasting all the other "mass killing" IFPs, so I thought I'd forecast on this one, too. I will say, though, of all the mass killing IFPs, this is the one that concerns me (in that I think it could resolve affirmatively without there being a helpful stream of news stories to tell us about a build up). Of course, I could be way off. When looking for information on this IFP, I checked EWP (as I have for all the other IFPs on this challenge), and there aren't any questions on EWP's site like they're asking here (for this IFP), so it's a bit of "flying blind." With that being said, I did stumble onto something that I think will be helpful for this IFP and for the other "mass killing" IFPs. EWP's Statistical Risk Assessment --> http://www.earlywarningproject.com/risk_assessments In particular, notice the graph on the top right: "Historical Trends in Episodes of State-Led Mass Killing" In it, you can see that the "ongoing episodes" have had a sharp decline starting in the early 90s. In the last 5 years, there've been approximately 9 ongoing episodes (for each year, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, and 2015). Also in the last 5 years, there've been approximately 7 NEW episodes. There were three each in 2011 and 2013 (and then one in 2010).  I'm not sure that we can definitively say this helps us, as one episode of mass killing in Burundi isn't necessarily linked to one episode of mass killing in Nigeria (or the DRC), but I think it's at least helpful to familiarize ourselves with this kind of data.
